data.message:
Nice article. Unfortunately I found that some people don't know a lot about passwords.

I suggest that you add a little explanation of what are the differences between bcrypt & sha1 hashing, so people know what they should use

In encryption you can get back the decrypted password by knowing the key, so the idea is where to store the key ?. however, while performing hashing on a string, you can not get back to the original string.

I would like to note also something about using hashing. You can get collisions so easily ( a repeated hash), so you need to use open addressing, or any methods that appears in algorithms books. Also using hashing is so fast, o(1) or o(n) worst case, so its better to use it to look for people's passwords in database instead of using their names..etc.

1. Hashing passwords should be slow. If it's fast, it will be easier to break. Fast hashes (like MD5) are for file validation
2. If you use hashed password only for user lookup without using salt, you can log in if you write the password for _any_ user
